Fits 25 x 75 mm slides

Short story - a rough model of a power tool battery pack. All sorts of uses, including a wall mount to hold the power tools. Long story follows...  
Here in Oz-land what used to be a widely available set of cordless power tools has now been monopolised by one hardware store chain.   
So now you can only get them at a non-competative price at Bunnings. But they are relatively cheep and do the job.  
That however doesn't distract from their wide range of tools utilising a common 18-volt battery design. I have a couple of drills, demolition-saw, sanders, multi-tool, hand-vac, angle-grinder, circular-saw, router, whipper-snipper and a few different batteries (old ni-cad & new lithiumin two sizes) and an 8 port battery charger. (There are a few more investment opertunities left too.;)  
So, I wall mounted the 8 port battery charger (and the 36-volt big brother - another story), but wanted to have an easy way to mount all the tools too.  
Hence, I needed a model of the battery pack to make a holder.  
It took me a while, gave me an introduction on techniques and appproaches to modeling existing real objects, which I may share later, But this is the result.  
I'm not familiar with many other brands of batteries, but if yours is similar you may be able to use this SCAD as the base of a design too, I even included a picture. Note the range of quick & dirty modules at the bottom to get various cuts/angles.

Choose the forward or back 5 degree pack, depending on thich way your tool mounts, print, screw to wall, mount your drill/whatever.  
I got some corner lift with ABS with higher infill, even at 100C, may want to keep it low.  
Note: Some items like the hand-vac need a bigger battery block to clear the tool (ie the large battery sits flush with the bottom of the tool), I'll be making a thicker wedge to suit. Just did, I made it flat so the vac lines up with the wall, should be printable with low fill - I hope.  
The 5 degree STLs can look bad (but function) on large slice sizes where the angled flat bits get a stepped look. If that matters, print the wedge shape, and glue to the thin flat pack; you will need to drill out the wedge.

comments.text:
I saw these batteries on Ebay for $13.33 for 10 of them:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/10pcs-x-18650-3-7V-9800mAh-Yellow-Li-ion-Rechargeable-Battery-Cell-For-Torch-SS1-/222299767445?var=&hash=item33c2194295:m:mK1Clg5b6qhXp7f7OEjrdFw
and thought about putting 5 in series to give the needed 18v and then making may own battery pack for the Ryobi.
3.7v each at 9800mAh should give lots of power for a long time, especially using 2 sets of 5 in parallel... the biggest
hassle would be charging them since you couldn't use the Ryobi charger to do it... but it should be really lightweight.
comments.author: WillieNAz

comments.text: I know this is an old comment, but I just want to make it clear that those batteries are outright frauds, most likely crappy recycled cells, and very likely dangerous at that.  I've seen 18650s that have sawdust and a tiny 500mah lipo soldered to the terminals inside.
comments.author: WillieNAz

comments.text: Note that, I think, the battery packs have an over-discharge protection circuit, to preserve the batteries. Also IIRC one of the connectors is T for temperature, which is used to regulate the charge current so they don't get over charged.
comments.author: WillieNAz

comments.text: Thanks for that.  I noticed when I repaired one of my battery packs that there is a thermistor inside so it can shut it down if it gets too hot.  I don't know enough about battery chargers to try charging Li-ions in anything but what they are made for, so I'd have to buy a charger that will charge 10 of them at a time and pull them all out each time it needs charging, but 9800mAh should needed charging pretty rarely, and if I have a backup even sweeter!

remixed_from.author: Waltermixxx
remixed_from.title: Auto Level for Folger Prusa i3 mount

title: Auto Level for Folger Prusa i3

description.text:
Here is my version of the auto level arm and servo mount for use with the Folger Tech Prusa i3 in conjunction with the upgraded spring loaded extruder feeder. The arm switch mounting holes are spaced such that the Folger z end stop switch may be mounted. Servo mount is sized for a SG90 servo.   
SINGLE BEST UPGRADE TO MY PRINTER!!!  
Make sure to upgrade to the latest Marlin Firmware if you plan on Auto leveling!!  Also, go ahead and pick up some spare nuts for z axis (5mm for folger), the auto level tends to eat them up with the constant  movement......easy 10 min swap when they do go.

comments.text: Have you tried greasing the nuts on the z axis on to preserve them? Also is their any damage to the threaded rod?

comments.text: I uploaded my Configuration.h file.  Your extruder offsets will likely be different, but if you have a Folger Prusa i3 everything should be pretty close.  I do use a Reprap Full Graphics LCD, so if you use something else you'll have to make sure to turn off (comment out) the LCD lines. Use the newest Marlin code and either change the Configuration.h settings to match your original configuration file or match what I uploaded.

This is recreation of a Roman ballista. Its small (obviously), and isn't an exact replica (Romans didn't work in plastic). Its about the right size to fire a pencil. It should be fairly obvious how it works, but I have some instructions below, and a short movie. P.S. I am aware of the Thingiverse policy not to publish "weapons". I see this as a toy -- it can fire a pencil about two feet with considerably less force than I can throw it. However, please be careful as points can always put out eyes. Also I know someone could potentially beef this up until it fires knives at a 100 miles and hour. Please don't. TODO: this is a work in progress because there's some things I want to add.
-- a mounting point so you can put it on a "table" (a stand on a pedestal).
-- a ratchet, winch and trigger mechanism, that are vaguely period

(1) Print out the parts:
1 of each of the body parts (technically these should be called the ladder)
1 pair of arms
2 frames
2 pairs of winders
Clean the pieces up, and maybe smooth the bore of the body parts a bit. (2) Assemble: see pictures for some help if needed.
  • put the two body parts together. They click nicely into place when made with my settings
  • put the two frame parts around the matching inset part of the body. Again they should nicely click.
  • put a pair of rubber bands through a winder, then an arm, and then a second winder. Then you can push the winders through the holes in the frame so that the arm is suspended between the frame. Repeat on the other side. Make sure the arms are facing the right way (see pictures).
  • wind up the winders to put tension on the rubber bands. They don't need to be too tight, but its helpful to have the top and bottom be about the same.
  • attach a piece of string to the ends of each arm, so that it is just under tension (i.e., not loose, but not too tight either). The string should pass through the slot in the body.
  • now the fiddly bit -- pull back the arms, and the string between them so that you can just reach it through the back hole of the body. Tie a second bit of string to the middle of the first piece. the idea is that the second piece pulls back the first piece of string, and hence the arms. A big knot is OK here as it helps catch the pencil.
    • Now you are done.

comments.text: I assembled mine using a strong string, and it worked nicely and it shoots quite far. I almost cannot twist the winders any more, since i need some tool and quite some force to lift up the end of the winders. It does stress the parts quite much, but my print was great so they are very solid (thanks to my stepstruder).
comments.author: jballard

comments.text: Just an FYI, torsion springs DO scale down very well. I made a little onager catapult out of wood and used nylon kite string. It LAUNCHES stuff! Definitely could be dangerous with a pencil though  O:-)
comments.author: jballard

comments.text: On this scale, rubber bands will have more power than a "true" torsion spring. Torsion springs don't scale down well, as the elasticity of the material doesn't scale much at all. Also, a torsion spring with string would put an enormous amount of force on the printed parts, which I'm not confident they'd handle so well.
comments.author: jballard

comments.text: I wasn't trying to get super-power out of it, and I think you're right that it couldn't take a huge amount of force, but it can definitely take more than the puny rubber bands I have at present. However, the winders were designed with something stretchable in mind -- you'd probably want to mod them for something with less elastic qualities, even if it would work -- as noted it probably wouldn't.

Your Countertop kit can never be complete if you are missing your MAKER-CUT.   
MAKER-CUT is a portable cutting board perfect for your Micro-Kitchen or the weekend grill, when you flip it you can fit your 3 favorite sharpest knives so you can carry them securely in the bottom, it also has a convenient container where you can step aside what you have already cut leaving a full space in your cutting board to cut whatever comes next.

-10% to 15% fill
-2-3 Layers
-I used supports on the container to ensure the quality of the rails

Original measurement of the cutting board is 190 x 120 mm you can scale it to 130% an it will measure 247 x 156 mm, that is near to the biggest size you can reach in the Maker bot, remember to scale the container also to 130%

Made this for my wife to put her hair dryer in that's convenient against the wall. There are three versions:

  • Two screws with slot style wall mounting. This one works perfectly fine, you just need to get the screws tight and then it almost acts like a snap fit. I have this one and haven't had it rotate out of place. I like the look of it which is why I'm using it.

  • Three screws for maximum securing for preventing rotation. This will absolutely prevent any sort of rotation. I haven't seen the need for it myself, but I imagine some people would want it.

  • Flat back with no screw holes. This is in response to a request to make it usable with a Tesa Powerstrip (basically double sided tape) that is 5 x 2cm. Made it 1mm taller than the other models to bump it up from 1.95cm to 2.05cm thick.
    • Hope you enjoy it! Certainly made my wife happy haha If you have any questions/comments/improvements please feel free to leave a comment or shoot me a message. -Mike Updated 2015-03-31 Added third version

This is a simple solution for an old problem.  
I was tired of waiting for the hair gel to flow to spout when I turned the bottle over. This device holds the bottle upside down so the gel is always ready to dispense immediately.  
This would also work well for shampoo bottles that are nearly empty.  
The holder is sized for a 28.5 mm diameter hole that is about 25 mm long. This gave the 27.5 mm cap, 1 mm clearance on the diameter.  
For other hole sizes simply scale the .stl by the following ratio:  
ratio = (new hole diameter)/(28mm)

This is a shaving bowl I made for people that use just bar soap and a foaming brush to make lather. Some of the fun features I put in:
  • Snap fit lid for an "elegant" feel and to make it great for travelling without worrying about the soap falling out.
  • Small spikes in bottom to hold soap in place. Since I use the left over soap from the shower once it gets too small, having spikes to press it into is really handy so it doesn't move around.
  • A 2.5" OD (outer diameter) stainless steel ring can be epoxied into the bottom as shown in the pictures (grab it at your local hardware store). It isn't necessary but it adds some really nice heft to it. Tricks your mind into not really noticing that it's plastic and adds a nice premium feel to it.
    • Hope you guys enjoy! -Mike

description.text: In my ongoing quest to eliminate or supersede all things Matlab, I present a functional solution to the problem of extruding along arbitrary contours, written in python. This is a reaction to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7080, itself a derivative of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6923. Credit to both these authors for the concept and motivation. Parameters are specified at the top of the script. A closed curve in 3D is specified as f:tâ†’(x,y,z) a parametric function of t. A closed curve in 2D is specified as f:sâ†’(x,y) and is used as the cross-section to extrude along the 3D curve. Bonus : If you manually specify the "crosssection" matrix, which is a lost of [x,y] points around the perimeter, you can extrude arbitrary cross-sections. download, cut, edit, steal, modify, repost, use, go. update : I added knot.py, which simply explicitly defines the knot equations at the top and adds a couple integer parameters, similar too http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6923.

• requires python, numpy
  • edit the functions and s,t ranges in the script
  • for knot.py, just play around with the integers at the top of the file
  • python stextrude.py myoutput.stl
  • might want to adjust resolution if the script takes too long

If I enclose the Ethernet Shield , the enclosure will be very thick.
So I change my mind , I use Raspberry Pi as Web Server and connect it via USB.
Then Pi send command via USB for get the PH and Temperature data. So in this way , it also be networkable. But it need to host by Pi.
That's why the firmware have API for serial communication.
And now , I am thinking to connect it via TTL to Wifi module. The enclosure can also host the TTL to Wifi module inside. But I need to solve the power source. Since the TTL to Wifi module is 3.3v , 300ma , cannot use UNO's 3.3V as power supply.

author: JM22254

description.text:
I couldn't figure out why the current OpenBuilds NEMA 17 mounting plate allows the belt to drag along the extrusion.  I felt that the best way to do this was to have the center of the motor and idler pulley be placed so that the belt will run above the surface of the V-Slot extrusion, as well utilze the empty space inside of the extrusion.  
Once this prints out, I'll start making a revised idler pulley mounting plate as well.

comments.text: I just uploaded a couple more pictures with the plate mounted on my 20x40 stick.  It's clearly still not the right belt position, yet there isn't enough room.  The options are to either go with a larger pulley (not a good idea if you want to preserve resolution), or add an idler to move the belt above the surface of the extrusion.

title: Garmin Etrex support for the stem of your mountain bike

description.text:
I designed this support to fit my Specialized Stumpjumper 75mm stem. Thanx to 2015.06.03 shape revision, it now probably fits even (few millimiters) shorter stems. On stems of different brands... sorry, can't tell ... but I guess it could fit too (lower support radius is 19 mm - I use a piece of air chamber between support and stem) Please consider it costed me several attempts and some time to reach final, shared, result; so, please, be nice with critics :-) Please enjoy my design and don't forget to wear helmet while riding your mtb ;-) Updates:
  • Lower_2015.06.03.stl - Base support on the stem.
    This release is a redesigned support ti fit even stems shorter than 75 mm.
  • Upper_2015.06.03.stl - Upper slide to the Garmin Etrex.
    Minor modifications to fit 2015.06.03 lower support.
    • 03.06.2015 Update.
    It works great on my bike !

Please go with ABS (PLA is too easy to break). Some poerative suggestions (but you may find your own also):
  • Temp: 250°C to 260°C
  • Layer thickness: 0,15 mm
  • Infill: 30%
  • Shell thickness: 2 mm
  • Bottom/top: 1 mm
  • Support type: touching buildplate (meant for the small teeth)
    • I designed it in two parts because it will be easier to replace the upper slide in case of crash or in case the elastic arm would break with normal use. Re-printing just upper piece will be easier and less time-consuming than printing all the structure.

And another geometric tiling for the Eggbot. This one somewhat reminiscent of Op Art. The drawing is in a 3200 by 800 pixel template.
Generating this and similar images is fairly simple. For example, this image was generated by drawing a square, then splitting the square into two triangles.  Each triangle was then twisted using the contributed "twist" extension under Extensions > Eggbot Contributed. The result was then cloned & tiled using Inkscape's Edit > Clone > Create Tiled Clones... tool.
See also Thing 6968.

The drawing is in two layers:
1 - test -- this is a framing layer which you can plot (with or without a pen) to ensure that you have the pen's starting position where you want it. Plot this using the "Layers" tab of the Eggbot Control extension and select "1" for the layer. A short tick mark at y=800 and another at y=0 will be drawn.
2 - drawing -- this is the actual drawing.
If you are having slippage issues and the drawing leaves a gap between the start and finish, you can horizontally stretch the drawing a few pixels using Inkscape's transformation tools. Select everything in layer "2 - drawing" and then use Object > Transform. Select the scale tab and set the units to pixels.

comments.text: I hate to be critical but I was finally looking into this model as well as the real PRS stock and there is no way this model is functional at all.  First of all an A2 buffer tube is far far longer than what you left room for, it goes almost all the way to the butt pad and is held on by a screw right under the butt pad (which there is no hole for).  Also there is no way one screw will be solid on the butt pad or even cheek riser for that matter.  The real PRS has two screw system on each.   So really all you have here is a start of a model that needs some major additions to become functional.  I am very glad I didn't print it yet.

The tangram is a dissection puzzle consisting of seven flat shapes, called tans, which are put together to form shapes. The objective of the puzzle is to form a specific shape (given only in outline or silhouette) using all seven pieces, which may not overlap.[1] My nieces have a tangram book, but had lost the pieces, so I made a few copies on the NYC Resisor laser cutter. [1] http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tangram
Laser cut and enjoy.

Derivative of thing 7064, Thermocouple sensor, single sided carrier board by moleofproduction ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7064 ). The Mole of Production asked for a "proper Eagle version if anyone wants to put in the time," so here is one version.

The board is a single-sided design (as MoP's original), but has added holes for mounting with stand-offs (footprints from the Sparkfun EAGLE library.) The connector footprints are 1" (2.54mm) which should accommodate either the 4-pin mini-terminal-blocks as in the original design, or inexpensive pin headers or female sockets, but these are as of yet untested. Updates for V1.01:
As per ednisley's suggestion, a solder jumper has been added between T- and GND to enable open thermocouple detection. A large ground plane has been added to improve the temperature measurement accuracy as per the MAX6675 datasheet. Knowing some may wish to etch their own boards at home, and having experience with the laser toner transfer etching method myself, line widths and clearances of the artwork have been increased. If you don't wish to make it yourself, you can also get boards from BatchPCB:
http://batchpcb.com/index.php/Products/56827

Let me hide that dust I don't want to see! Not sure why, but the LED on the Makerbot Replicator Mini is flush to the bottom of the printer. Being in that spot, the smallest dust can be seen and it look ugly. Truely.
Don't tell me it's because I don't clean my home, 3 secondes just after vaccum cleaning it, you can see dust... It's frustating. So just plug that in the LED spot and boom: much much less dust can be seen. It doesn't affect the overall lightning of the LED, simply redirect it. Indeed, it does not remove dust... Just hiding it to your eyes. Changelog:
v1.1 : Snap added to secure it so it won't move.
Some model are not there, you can find more here: https://www.cgtrader.com/M600

comments.text: Decided to try this for my MakerBot Mini and it's awesome! It did it's job so nicely that I just went ahead and superglued it to my printer. It really does hide all the annoying dust particles that refuse to go away. A very nice build to the maker of this design.

Eine solche File ist besonders gut geeignet für Hartmetalle und Kunststoffe aller Art. Am besten eignet sich Sandpapier auf Textiluntergrund. Dieses kann man gut reißen! Schneiden, gar mit einer Schere, ist nicht sinnvoll.  
Alle meine hier eingestellten Teile wurde ausgedruckt und geprüft, bzw. verbessert. Auch stelle ich gleichzeitig den FREECAD Arbeitsfile mit ein, sodass versierte Hobbyisten sich das Werkstück anders gestalten können.  
Das Werkstück ist 14 cm lang. Nichtrostende Senkkopfschraube M4 (20 mm Länge)  mit Mutter.  
(Übersetzung erfolgte bei Googel)  
Sandpaper emery file  
Such a file is particularly well suited for hard metals and plastics of all types. The best sand paper is on textile background. This can be good tear! Cutting, even with scissors is not useful.  
All my parts here set was printed and tested, and improved. Also I put the same file freecad work with a so-savvy hobbyists can make the work differently.  
The workpiece is 14 cm long. Stainless countersunk screw M4 (20 mm length) with mother.  
(Translation was carried out at Googel)

My fellow Thingicans and Thingocrats; thanks to your help, this project is well under way! BACKGROUND (robot): The Wowwee Rovio ( http://www.wowwee.com/en/products/tech/telepresence/rovio/rovio ) is a IP-based Wifi Mobile Webcam, sometimes marketed as a simple telepresence robot. At a price point of about $200, it's money well spent; the system is very well designed both in hardware and software, and you'd have a /very difficult/ time duplicating the ability of this robot for twice the price. The robot itself is rather hackable, with a well-documented and full-featured web API. The source code to the mainboard was grudgingly released a while back, too, but I've not examined it and I'm told it's useless. BACKGROUND (tracking): The robot uses a system from Evolution Robotics called "Northstar" for indoor spatial positioning. The system is very simple at it's most basic concept; the robot has a tiny pinhole camera mounted on it's top. The camera looks at the ceiling for two infrared dots that are projected by a 'Truetrack Beacon.' You could think of it as working very much like a Wiimote. Evolution Robotics makes sales-level information available here, for an overview of the system: http://www.evolution.com/products/northstar/ The system uses an 'encoding' to allow the Rovio to uniquely identify up to 10 different tracking beacons; the base station it comes with (beacon #0) and up to 9 additional beacon units, which WERE sold separately for a very short time (advertised here: http://www.wowwee.com/en/products/tech/telepresence/rovio/truetrack-room-beacon ). The additional beacon units have a simple switch to select the ID. MOTIVATION: Sadly, the Rovio is a dead-end product; the manufacturer (Wowwee) never supported it very well and now has confirmed that they have stopped production and don't intend to ever bring it back. New tracking beacons cannot be gotten for love or money, and despite the popularity of this product among hackers at one point, there is no data on the actual signaling protocol used by the Northstar system. Unfortunately, they won't talk to me, and they want /thousands/ for the development kits for the Northstar product, so following legitimate channels is out. In addition, if they /were/ to fork over the details, I'd bet it would put my under an NDA that would prevent publication. As I don't have /ANY/ tracking beacons (except the one built into the base station), my Rovio is somewhat limited in it's automatic positioning abilities. WHAT WAS PREVIOUSLY KNOWN: All the gritty information on the Rovio seems to be concentrated on one site; robocommunity.com. Here's a thread where some folks dissect the robot and tracking station:
http://www.robocommunity.com/forum/thread/14360/Inside-Rovio/ The board we're interested in here is the round one, which is the Northstar beacon projector PCB. There's a lot of great info on it specifically on this thread and the comments: http://www.robocommunity.com/article/15353/Inside-the-WowWee-Rovio-TrueTrack-Beacon/ Unfortunately, no information on how it actually signals. WHAT I'VE LEARNED SO FAR: From looking at the photos in the above thread before I got my robot (I've only had it for one day!) I'd guessed that the signaling protocol was as simple as flashing the two IR lights at different rates. That seems like the simple and obvious method to tell both one light in a beacon from the other, and to tell one set of lights for a beacon from the other. So I opened up my beacon in the base station (instructions in the linked thread), and put a scope on the transistors that drive the LEDs. From my photos, you will see my conjecture seemed to be correct; the LEDs were being blinked at very specific and different rates. Wiring up a quick circuit with an Arduino to blink a couple of LEDs at the same rate, I took the Rovio and exposed it to my LEDs. SURE ENOUGH, it immediately recognized it as Tracking Beacon #0, the home station. SUCCESS! The MAJOR problem is - I only know the signaling speed to reproduce beacon #0, and you can't have two #0s in a network, so what I have so far is only good for people whos base station is destroyed. With the signaling rates here, you can easily build a charging/dock/beacon0 unit from scratch. If you want the actual rates, they're in my o-scope photo(s). :) UPDATE (2011-03-18): I built an automated scanner, which I'll leave to run all night, but it's already produced results! I have a workable ID for NAV BEACON #1. That's one down, 8 to go! Even if I find them all, though, I could STILL use someone with a scope and real beacon to double-check my work... I'll be posting some pretty graphs and photos and probably the fuzzing circuit and software shortly. UPDATE: 2011-03-20 I've been running my scanner for the last day and I'm posting some quick charts as well as the data I've gotten so far. I'm not going to make any claims the data is good, but it has yielded some interesting points! I also uploaded the latest copies of the scanner software but I'm not sure I've made any noteworthy changes. UPDATE2: 2011-03-20 I've built a simple tracking station and placed it in my home, and begun testing. Two things I can report immediately: 1) Getting proper coverage from an LED is not easy, and I'll either have to use an array of LEDs, or a lens, or try the wide angle LEDs I have on order, or some combination of the above. 2) The actual frequencies for room ID #1 reported by botman work better than my 1/3rd frequency in practice. UPDATES (2011-04-10):
This is mostly a summary of what's in the comments below. I've decided to move forward using stations based around a pair of transistors (I'll likely use some FETs since we're going to push > 100ma - maybe much > and also because they reduce component count) driving current into a pair of TSAL7200 LEDs (sourced here: http://www.rentron.com/remote_control/IRLED.htm) with the gates switched by a Atmega8, which can be programmed to a given station ID through SPI. I'll post the circuit the way I have it laid out so far; if anyone can come up with a good single-sided layout for printing and etching at home you'll be doing better than I am; I keep ending up with a few jumper wires required. Keep in mind this circuit hasn't actually been built or tested as posted. Here's a quick reference of the known station ID frequencies: 3030 and 2010 = Room 0
3150 and 2070 = Room 1
4170 and 3210 = Room 2
4290 and 3330 = Room 3
4410 and 3450 = Room 4
4530 and 3570 = Room 5
4650 and 3690 = Room 6
4770 and 3810 = Room 7
4890 and 3930 = Room 8
5010 and 4050 = Room 9

HERE IS A LINK TO THE THREAD I STARTED AT ROBOCOMMUNITY just for completeness, but let's be honest, those forums are a bit dead. I think I missed the exciting times for this product. :) http://www.robocommunity.com/forum/thread/18385/How-To-Build-your-own-Rovio-Northstar-Beacon/

SOME ACTUAL INSTRUCTIONS!
There are a perl file and Arduino project (c++ avr) attached.
Wire up two infrared LEDs to an arduino, one on pin 9, the other on 10.  Put them directly on or above your bot's sensor and run the test() function in the perl module to check to make sure everything is working.  You should get the max value for signal strenght (65535) when it is right, and something low when it is wrong.
Then you can use the perl file to scan whatever frequencies you think Northstar might have used and make your own beacons from them!
I'm still scanning, more details as they arrive - but it's going VERY well.  I've attached a fancygraph of the results that are in thus far.  My fiance would kill me for the unlabeled axes; they are X+Y frequency of LED blink in hz, Z = bot's reported signal strength.  The script also tracks which beacon ID is reported for each sufficiently strong signal, but I couldn't figure out how to get it on the graph. :)
I'll post plans for a circuit as soon as I've developed it further than "stick a couple LEDs on a Atmega, switched by transistors."

MCU is a ATTiny85 (although a '45 or even a '25 would work).

This mini cutting board was designed with the Makerbot Replicator in mind, and features a unique design for those who need exact measurements on their cuts. One side features slices spaced at half inch intervals while the opposite side features quarter inch intervals.   
To make it easier for those using a chef's knife (or any knife in general), the slices in the board have been curved gently from the middle outwards.  
I hope you (and especially those of you with as much of an OCD as myself) enjoy this cutting board design.
See "Design and Details.pdf" document in downloads.

description.text:
Warjacks / Laborjacks are steam powered golems part of the WARMACHINE game from Privateer Press.   
This model is inspired by their designs.  
A trial run without any real measurements off any existing model.   
lots of gluing required, and I found that running a pin/paperclip from the chassis down to the crotch helps it all keep together.  
no hands or head yet and alot of putty / green stuff work needed to make it smooth and add detail work.  but sine I print at .3mm layers, I wasn't worried about fine detail printing.  
sketchup file included for those who want to complete their own.

author: stapleto391

description.text: Updated the design of the stock emax nighthawk 250 pro quadcopter arms with a more sturdy build. I've eliminated as many of the styling cut outs as they induce weak points near the base of the arm. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/bggY3h5iNkh

comments.text:
How thick is your arm? I beefed it up too. Since the stock arm was 4.2mm & the metal spacer on top is 5mm thick, I beefed up the arm to 5.5mm & added a 2.5mm perimeter wall on top, as in my first photo:
http://thingiverse-production-new.s3.amazonaws.com/renders/cc/45/5e/36/fe/10987380_10104222959791546_2358183929333530204_n_preview_featured.jpg
I haven't gotten it up in the air yet, else I would have released that arm.
comments.author: scratchymaster

comments.text: This arm is 5mm thick along the length of the arm, and 6mm thick at the motor mount to get it up a little higher over the ESC's.  I may change this back to 5mm after a test print tomorrow.  I have found that these arms tend to fail at the points between the routed styling cut outs.  I have kept the arm to (near) original dimensions though.
comments.author: scratchymaster

title: Set of Hex Spacer M3/M4 (5mm - 50mm + custom)

description.text:
A set of hex spacers I made, very handy for electronics, quadcopters, etc... M3 - 5mm to 50mm, (+5mm).
M4 - 5mm to 50mm, (+5mm). Dimensions:
M3 - Ø3mm/Ø6mm
M4 - Ø4mm/Ø8mm There's a SketchUp file in which you can push/pull the hex spacer to your desired height.

Print it 100% fill for rough use, or >20% for static stuff.
Prints with hex face on bed.

comments.text: Pro tip for anyone printing these, lay them flat and they are much stronger.
